tag-polygon tag-programming tag-python"><p><a href="http://www.j-raedler.de/wp-content/uploads/2010/06/polylogo300.png"><img decoding="async" class="alignleft size-thumbnail wp-image-837" title="polylogo300" src="http://www.j-raedler.de/wp-content/uploads/2010/06/polylogo300-150x150.png" alt="Polygon logo" width="150" height="150" srcset="https://www.j-raedler.de/wp-content/uploads/2010/06/polylogo300-150x150.png 150w, https://www.j-raedler.de/wp-content/uploads/2010/06/polylogo300-100x100.png 100w" sizes="(max-width: 150px) 100vw, 150px" /></a><a href="http://www.j-raedler.de/tag/polygon" target="_self" rel="noopener">|View all articles regarding Polygon|</a></p><p>Polygon is a <a href="http://www.python.org" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Python</a> package that handles polygonal shapes in 2D. It contains Python bindings for gpc, the excellent General Polygon Clipping Library by Alan Murta and some extensions written in C and pure Python. With Polygon you may handle complex polygonal shapes in Python in a very intuitive way. Polygons are simple Python objects, clipping operations are bound to standard operators like +, -, |, & and ^. TriStrips can be constructed from Polygons with a single statement. Functions to compute the area, center point, convex hull, point containment and much more are included.</p><p>Points can be organized in tuples or lists. <a href="http://www.numpy.org/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">NumPy</a> arrays are also supported but Polygon can be compiled without support for it.</p><p><strong>This package was already used to process shapes with more than one million points!</strong></p><ul><li>License: LGPL (not for gpc itself, see below!)</li><li>Status: Should be almost stable now, but there may be memory leaks. Malformed files and illegal contours may crash the library and your running Python interpreter! Use Polygon at your own risk or don’t use it at all!</li><li>gpc-Homepage: http://www.cs.man.ac.uk/~toby/alan/software/</li></ul><p>gpc is included in Polygon, you don’t need to download it separately. I made two small changes to gpc:</p><ol><li>fixed warnings regarding a printf format string and</li><li>made GPC_EPSILON adjustable, this may slow down the clipping a little bit.</li></ol><p>The author of gpc (Alan Murta) is not responsible for this distribution! The wrapping and extension code is free software, but the core gpc library is free for non-commercial usage only. The author says:</p><p><em>GPC is free for non-commercial use only. We invite non-commercial users to make a voluntary donation towards the upkeep of GPC. If you wish to use GPC in support of a commercial product, you must obtain an official GPC Commercial Use Licence from The University of Manchester.</em></p><p>Please respect this statement and contact the author (see <a href="http://www.cs.man.ac.uk/~toby/alan/software/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">gpc homepage</a>) if you wish to use this software in commercial projects!</p><h2>Download, Documentation & Examples</h2><p>The package can be downloaded from the <a href="https://pypi.python.org/pypi" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Python Package Index PyPI</a>:</p><ul><li><a href="https://pypi.python.org/pypi/Polygon3" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Polygon3</a> for Python 3.1 and newer</li><li><a href="https://pypi.python.org/pypi/Polygon2" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Polygon2</a> for Python 2.6 and 2.7 – old and unmaintained!</li></ul><p>The development files as well as documentation and examples are hosted at GitHub.  There are two different projects:</p><ul><li><a href="https://github.com/jraedler/Polygon3" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Polygon3</a></li><li><a href="https://github.com/jraedler/Polygon2" target="_blank" December 2013 at 09:08</a></div><p>Hi Diederik,<br />no, I don’t think there’s an easier way, sorry!</p><p>Jörg</p><div class="reply"><a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-login" href="https://www.j-raedler.de/wp-login.php?redirect_to=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.j-raedler.de%2Fprojects%2Fpolygon%2F">Log in to Reply</a></div></div></li><!-- #comment-## --></ul><!-- .children --></li><!-- #comment-## --><li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1 parent" id="comment-9034"><div id="div-comment-9034" class="comment-body"><div class="comment-author vcard"><img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/dbd317d5bb9760a983d9d4fcb9831ee3?s=64&d=mm&r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/dbd317d5bb9760a983d9d4fcb9831ee3?s=128&d=mm&r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-64 photo' height='64' width='64' loading='lazy' decoding='async'/><cite class="fn">GeorgeB</cite> <span class="says">says:</span></div><div class="comment-meta commentmetadata"><a href="https://www.j-raedler.de/projects/polygon/#comment-9034">18. November 2013 at 18:41</a></div><p>Hi  Jörg,</p><p>I’m sorry but I don’t quite understand from the documentation how I should input the fill color for when I save a svg:</p><p>For example if I want the width and height to be 1000 and the rgb to be 128,128,230 how do I do it ?</p><p>Ex of what I’ve been trying:</p><p>writeSVG(“my.svg”,polyCircle,1000,1000,(128,128,230);</p><div class="reply"><a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-login" href="https://www.j-raedler.de/wp-login.php?redirect_to=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.j-raedler.de%2Fprojects%2Fpolygon%2F">Log in to Reply</a></div></div><ul class="children"><li class="comment byuser comment-author-jraedler bypostauthor even depth-2" id="comment-9054"><div id="div-comment-9054" class="comment-body"><div class="comment-author vcard"><img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a1f5abbf6925c9aa055792da709fc2da?s=64&d=mm&r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a1f5abbf6925c9aa055792da709fc2da?s=128&d=mm&r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-64 photo' height='64' width='64' loading='lazy' decoding='async'/><cite class="fn"><a href="http://www.j-raedler.de/" class="url" rel="ugc">jraedler</a></cite> <span class="says">says:</span></div><div class="comment-meta commentmetadata"><a href="https://www.j-raedler.de/projects/polygon/#comment-9054">19. November 2013 at 12:15</a></div><p>writeSVG() expects a sequence (list, tuple, …) of polygons and sequences of the attributes, even if you have just one polygon object. A list with one element can be written <code>[e]</code>. A tuple with one element is written <code>(e,)</code>. A working example would be:<br /><code><br />import Polygon, Polygon.Shapes, Polygon.IO<br />p = Polygon.Shapes.Star()<br />Polygon.IO.writeSVG('out.svg', (p,), fill_color=((0, 255, 0),))<br /></code></p><p>Jörg</p><div class="reply"><a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-login" href="https://www.j-raedler.de/wp-login.php?redirect_to=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.j-raedler.de%2Fprojects%2Fpolygon%2F">Log in to Reply</a></div></div></li><!-- #comment-## --></ul><!-- .children --></li><!-- #comment-## --><li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1 parent" id="comment-8732"><div id="div-comment-8732" class="comment-body"><div class="comment-author vcard"><img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/732882750432021d33075abb057557d5?s=64&d=mm&r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/732882750432021d33075abb057557d5?s=128&d=mm&r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-64 photo' height='64' width='64' loading='lazy' decoding='async'/><cite class="fn">Diederik</cite> <span class="says">says:</span></div><div class="comment-meta commentmetadata"><a href="https://www.j-raedler.de/projects/polygon/#comment-8732">8. November 2013 at 06:14</a></div><p>Hi Jörg,</p><p>Is it possible to set the GPC_EPSILON without recompiling the GPC library? I’ve found out that I need a bigger value, but haven’t found a way to specify it directly in the Python code itself.</p><p>Thanks,</p><p>Diederik</p><div class="reply"><a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-login" href="https://www.j-raedler.de/wp-login.php?redirect_to=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.j-raedler.de%2Fprojects%2Fpolygon%2F">Log in to Reply</a></div></div><ul class="children"><li class="comment byuser comment-author-jraedler bypostauthor even depth-2 parent" id="comment-8739"><div id="div-comment-8739" class="comment-body"><div class="comment-author vcard"><img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a1f5abbf6925c9aa055792da709fc2da?s=64&d=mm&r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a1f5abbf6925c9aa055792da709fc2da?s=128&d=mm&r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-64 photo' height='64' width='64' loading='lazy' decoding='async'/><cite class="fn"><a href="http://www.j-raedler.de/" class="url" rel="ugc">jraedler</a></cite> <span class="says">says:</span></div><div class="comment-meta commentmetadata"><a href="https://www.j-raedler.de/projects/polygon/#comment-8739">8. November 2013 at 09:13</a></div><p>The Polygon module has two functions: setTolerance(tol) and getTolerance(), that should change or return the value of  GPC_EPSILON.</p><p>Jörg</p><div class="reply"><a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-login" href="https://www.j-raedler.de/wp-login.php?redirect_to=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.j-raedler.de%2Fprojects%2Fpolygon%2F">Log in to Reply</a></div></div><ul class="children"><li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="comment-8745"><div id="div-comment-8745" class="comment-body"><div class="comment-author vcard"><img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/732882750432021d33075abb057557d5?s=64&d=mm&r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/732882750432021d33075abb057557d5?s=128&d=mm&r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-64 photo' height='64' width='64' loading='lazy' decoding='async'/><cite class="fn">Diederik van Lierop</cite> <span class="says">says:</span></div><div class="comment-meta commentmetadata"><a href="https://www.j-raedler.de/projects/polygon/#comment-8745">8. November 2013 at 12:26</a></div><p>Hi Jörg,</p><p>The library looks great very intuitive, If I may ask  is there a method to export the shapes to some form of bitmap image format (for ex jpg) ?</p><p>Or would I have to use another library after I generate the images with yours ?</p><div class="reply"><a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-login" href="https://www.j-raedler.de/wp-login.php?redirect_to=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.j-raedler.de%2Fprojects%2Fpolygon%2F">Log in to Reply</a></div></div><ul class="children"><li class="comment byuser comment-author-jraedler bypostauthor odd alt depth-2" id="comment-8712"><div id="div-comment-8712" class="comment-body"><div class="comment-author vcard"><img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a1f5abbf6925c9aa055792da709fc2da?s=64&d=mm&r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a1f5abbf6925c9aa055792da709fc2da?s=128&d=mm&r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-64 photo' height='64' width='64' loading='lazy' decoding='async'/><cite class="fn"><a href="http://www.j-raedler.de/" class="url" rel="ugc">jraedler</a></cite> <span class="says">says:</span></div><div class="comment-meta commentmetadata"><a href="https://www.j-raedler.de/projects/polygon/#comment-8712">7. August 2013 at 18:19</a></div><p>*I cant understand the reason</p><div class="reply"><a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-login" href="https://www.j-raedler.de/wp-login.php?redirect_to=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.j-raedler.de%2Fprojects%2Fpolygon%2F">Log in to Reply</a></div></div></li><!-- #comment-## --></ul><!-- .children --></li><!-- #comment-## --><li class="comment even thread-even depth-1 parent" id="comment-4692"><div id="div-comment-4692" class="comment-body"><div class="comment-author vcard"><img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/732882750432021d33075abb057557d5?s=64&d=mm&r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/732882750432021d33075abb057557d5?s=128&d=mm&r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-64 photo' height='64' width='64' loading='lazy' decoding='async'/><cite class="fn">Diederik van Lierop</cite> <span class="says">says:</span></div><div class="comment-meta commentmetadata"><a href="https://www.j-raedler.de/projects/polygon/#comment-4692">11. June 2013 at 22:10</a></div><p>Hi Jörg,</p><p>When using writeSVG with a tuple of RGB values, the svg contains e.g. “fill:(255, 0, 0)”. This doesn’t work and should be “fill:rgb(255, 0, 0)” instead. See <a href="http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/types.html#DataTypeColor" rel="nofollow ugc">http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/types.html#DataTypeColor</a></p><p>Kind regards,</p><p>Diederik</p><div class="reply"><a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-login" href="https://www.j-raedler.de/wp-login.php?redirect_to=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.j-raedler.de%2Fprojects%2Fpolygon%2F">Log in to Reply</a></div></div><ul class="children"><li class="comment byuser comment-author-jraedler bypostauthor odd alt depth-2" id="comment-4755"><div id="div-comment-4755" class="comment-body"><div class="comment-author vcard"><img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a1f5abbf6925c9aa055792da709fc2da?s=64&d=mm&r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a1f5abbf6925c9aa055792da709fc2da?s=128&d=mm&r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-64 photo' height='64' width='64' loading='lazy' decoding='async'/><cite class="fn"><a href="http://www.j-raedler.de/" class="url" rel="ugc">jraedler</a></cite> <span class="says">says:</span></div><div class="comment-meta commentmetadata"><a href="https://www.j-raedler.de/projects/polygon/#comment-4755">13. June 2013 at 11:13</a></div><p>Thank you! This is fixed now in the repositores on bitbucket and will be part of the next release. Jörg</p><div class="reply"><a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-login" href="https://www.j-raedler.de/wp-login.php?redirect_to=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.j-raedler.de%2Fprojects%2Fpolygon%2F">Log in to Reply</a></div></div></li><!-- #comment-## --></ul><!-- .children --></li><!-- #comment-## --><li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1 parent" id="comment-4446"><div id="div-comment-4446" class="comment-body"><div class="comment-author vcard"><img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/732882750432021d33075abb057557d5?s=64&d=mm&r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/732882750432021d33075abb057557d5?s=128&d=mm&r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-64 photo' height='64' width='64' loading='lazy' decoding='async'/><cite class="fn">Diederik van Lierop</cite> <span class="says">says:</span></div><div class="comment-meta commentmetadata"><a href="https://www.j-raedler.de/projects/polygon/#comment-4446">5. June 2013 at 22:41</a></div><p>Hi Jörg,</p><p>Suppose I have a single solid polygon with multiple holes. Now when I do a boolean on it, I might end up with a single polygon consisting of multiple solids, with each solid having multiple holes. Is there an easy way to tell which holes belongs to which solid? I can iterate over all contours in the polygon and find out which are the solids and which are the holes, but that’s about it….</p><p>Of course I could look at all permutations and use the overlap() and covers() methods to find this out, but isn’t there an easier way?</p><p>Regards,</p><p>Diederik</p><div class="reply"><a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-login" href="https://www.j-raedler.de/wp-login.php?redirect_to=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.j-raedler.de%2Fprojects%2Fpolygon%2F">Log in to Reply</a></div></div><ul class="children"><li class="comment byuser comment-author-jraedler bypostauthor odd alt depth-2 parent" id="comment-4467"><div id="div-comment-4467" class="comment-body"><div class="comment-author vcard"><img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a1f5abbf6925c9aa055792da709fc2da?s=64&d=mm&r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a1f5abbf6925c9aa055792da709fc2da?s=128&d=mm&r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-64 photo' height='64' width='64' loading='lazy' decoding='async'/><cite class="fn"><a href="http://www.j-raedler.de/" class="url" rel="ugc">jraedler</a></cite> <span class="says">says:</span></div><div class="comment-meta commentmetadata"><a href="https://www.j-raedler.de/projects/polygon/#comment-4467">6. June 2013 at 12:10</a></div><p>Hi Diederik,</p><p>Sorry, I don’t think there’s an easier way. The list of solids and holes is returned by gpc, which does the clipping operations. May 2011 at 13:44</a></div><p>Hi Jörg,</p><p>Thanks very much for the tip. I was indeed working int the install library which was somewhat lazy of me. It works fine elsewhere!</p><p>I now have another issue – can you help me? I am looking to extend the code to provide grow and shrink operations for the polygons. I have already figured out the algorithm when I was using gpc with MATLAB – but now I want to use it with Python.</p><p>I would like to be able to overload the ‘+’ and ‘-‘ operators for this, so the following:</p><p>x=y+2</p><p>will make x a polygon that’s the y polygon grown by 2.</p><p>There appears to be strong type checking in the cPolygon.c and this causes an error when I try to implement the above. May 2011 at 14:10</a></div><p>The <strong>+</strong> and <strong>or</strong> operators are both mapped with the table <em>Polygon_NumberMethods</em> to the function <em>Polygon_opUnion</em> (everything in the file <em>cPolygon.c</em>). This function checks if both operands are Polygon objects. To change the behaviour of the <strong>+</strong>-operator you nedd to change the mapping and/or the function.</p><p>Joerg</p><div class="reply"><a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-login" href="https://www.j-raedler.de/wp-login.php?redirect_to=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.j-raedler.de%2Fprojects%2Fpolygon%2F">Log in to Reply</a></div></div></li><!-- #comment-## --></ul><!-- .children --></li><!-- #comment-## --><li class="comment byuser comment-author-jraedler bypostauthor odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="comment-431"><div id="div-comment-431" class="comment-body"><div class="comment-author vcard"><img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a1f5abbf6925c9aa055792da709fc2da?s=64&d=mm&r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a1f5abbf6925c9aa055792da709fc2da?s=128&d=mm&r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-64 photo' height='64' width='64' loading='lazy' decoding='async'/><cite class="fn"><a href="http://www.j-raedler.de/" class="url" rel="ugc">jraedler</a></cite> <span class="says">says:</span></div><div class="comment-meta commentmetadata"><a href="https://www.j-raedler.de/projects/polygon/#comment-431">30.
